titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Phillip Lopate Papers YCAL MSS 1083
titlestmt.author: by Emily Komornik

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Phillip Lopate papers consists of correspondence, writings, personal papers, teaching files, printed materials, and audiovisual and computer media documenting Lopate's career as a writer, critic, and university instructor. Materials date from circa 1951 to 2015.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Box 82 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 83 (audiovisual media): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Phillip Lopate and James S. Jaffe Rare Books LLC on the Sinclair Lewis Fund and the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into six series: I. Correspondence, circa 1958-2006 and undated. II. Writings, 1963-2009 and undated. III. Personal Papers, 1951-2000. IV. Teaching Materials, 1968-1975. V. Printed Materials, 1963-2015 and undated. VI. Computer and Audiovisual Media, 1934-2015 and undated.

bioghist.head: Phillip Lopate (1943-)
bioghist.p: Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1943, Phillip Lopate is the author of works of fiction, poetry, personal and literary essays, and film criticism. He is also the editor of several anthologies. Lopate received a B.A. from Columbia College of Columbia University in New York City in 1964 and his Ph.D. in English Education from Union Graduate School, in Cincinnati, Ohio in 1979. He has received various fellowships, including a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1988, and was inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2006. Lopate began his career as Project Director of the Teachers and Writers Collaborative in Manhattan, providing instruction to elementary school children in poetry and fiction writing, among other topics. After twelve years, he transitioned into higher education, holding teaching positions and professorships at institutions such as Hofstra University, Fordham University, New York University, and the University of Houston. He currently teaches nonfiction writing at Columbia's School of the Arts. Lopate's notable works include his memoir, Being With Children (1975), his essay collections Bachelorhood (1981), Getting Personal (2003), and The Rug Merchant (1987), a work of fiction.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Phillip Lopate Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing, indicated by brackets.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Phillip Lopate papers consists of correspondence, writings, personal papers, teaching files, printed materials, and audiovisual and computer media, dating from circa 1951 to 2015. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence with editors and publishers, notes, manuscripts, drafts, typescripts, proofs, and related materials that document his work as an essayist, literary critic, and author of short stories, poetry, biographies, and screenplays. Personal papers contain Lopate's personal diaries and journals, memo books, and notebooks, as well as interviews and news clippings about Lopate. Teaching files include Lopate's correspondence with other educators, student course evaluations, teaching diaries, and comics drawn by students at Public School 75 in Manhattan, New York. Printed materials contain publications authored or edited by Phillip Lopate, publications which feature his writing, and special edition publications. Computer and audiovisual media include interviews, lectures, and audio recordings on computer disks, optical media, audiocassettes, videocassettes, and film.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Phillip Lopate Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into ten subseries: Letters from family, Letters regarding film, Letters by [Phillip Lopate], Emails, mostly from friends, alphabetized, Lily Lopate (daughter/writer) correspondence and emails, Letters from old friends and frequent correspondents, Letters from the famous and near-famous, Older correspondence, Public appearances, translations, and business correspondence, and Reviews, publicity, and letters for books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series primarily consists of Phillip Lopate's correspondence with family, friends, writers, and critics such as Ron Padgett, David Shapiro, Rudy Burckhardt, Johnathan Cott, Sidney Tillim, Aaron Fogel, and Louise Glück. Other notable correspondents are Max Apple, Terry Caesar, Diana and Lionel Trilling, and Laura Furman. Included is an extensive amount of email correspondence with Lopate's daughter, author Lily Lopate, and correspondence with his mother Frances Lopate and brother Leonard. The series also contains correspondence related to Lopate's public appearances, such as lectures, speaking engagements, and interviews, as well as correspondence with publishers and agents.
The arrangement follows Lopate's original organization of his correspondence, and subseries and folder titles are based on the description he provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence with other writers and people Lopate considered "well-known," such as Max Apple, Diana and Lionel Trilling, and Cynthia Ozick, and those whom he considered "moderately-known," including Terry Caesar and Laura Furman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While Lopate described these letters as "older," they may be more recently dated than other correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Lopate's creative process and contains manuscripts, typescripts, proofs, research notes, reviews, and related materials for published and unpublished works, including essays, book reviews, literary criticism, poems, short stories, writings on film, screenplays, novels, and biographies of Rudy Burckhardt and Susan Sontag. Among the titles represented in the series are Lopate's first novel Best Friends, The Rug Merchant, Bachelorhood, the novella Two Marriages, and Spanish and Italian translations of Two Marriages. There are also manuscripts and typescripts of short stories and school papers written while Lopate was attending Columbia University. The series further contains printed versions of several works by Lopate, notably an inscribed limited-edition copy of the short story In Coyoacan (1971) and a page proof of The Anchor Essay Annual: Best of 1998. Heading and folder titles appearing in the contents list below are based on those provided by the creator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Shorter works, Books, Screenplays, Early works, and Printed materials

unittitle.emph: Teachers Guide to the Art of the Personal Essay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series primarily consists of Lopate's personal diaries and journals, memo books, and notebooks. Also present are interviews and news clippings about Lopate, dating from 1951 to 2000, which cover his academic and literary career. Diaries kept while he was a student are organized by year or semester. Later diaries span his early career as a teacher and writer, and some chronicle his travels to Russia, Israel, and other countries in the Middle East.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Diaries and journals, and Interviews and clippings about Phillip Lopate. Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Lopate's correspondence with other educators and students, student evaluations of courses he taught at Bennington College, Lopate's Hofstra University teaching diaries, comics drawn by children at Public School 75 in Manhattan, New York, and an edition of Black Cat, a comic book published by the PS 75 Comics Group under the guidance of Lopate and other teachers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Educational correspondence, student responses to and from Lopate, Student artwork and comic book drafts, and Teaching diaries, students. Arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications authored or edited by Phillip Lopate, publications which feature his writing, and special edition publications and unpublished proofs. Notable serials within Series V include the "Phillip Lopate Issue" of Blue Pig Magazine, circa 1970. Also present are many issues of Teachers and Writers magazine, including its special issues, The Whole World Catalogue, an academic publication for which Lopate sat on the Editorial and Advisory Boards, and wrote featured articles throughout the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes interviews, lectures, and audio recordings on computer disks, optical media, audiocassettes, videocassettes, and film. It also contains commercially produced optical media.
